person.note: In Georgian, see Introduction 2.8.5. The transliteration into Latin is taken from the index.
Described as “of the Jews,” see Introduction 6.1. The text describes this family’s conversion to Christianity. His name may thus be that of the entire family.
He is a contemporary of the Georgian king, who adopted Christianity in the days of Constantin the Great. These are his years.

So sometimes in the PT, e.g. in yBer 1:1, 3b. This form can tell us something of the pronunciation current in Palestine at the time. The name intended is obviously אבא, but since the initial א was often lost in the Palestinian dialect (see vol. 1, Introduction 2.5.2, p. 29) the result was that the name in use was בא. The double ו is a scribal practice indicating that the letter ו is here a consonant rather than a vowel, see Introduction 2.3.4.3. That this name was sometimes written as ווה indicates, I believe, that the initial ב was often pronounced as v rather than b. On this phenomenon see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 17.

There is some confusion about this family. According to PT Simlai was born in Nehardea (Babylonia) but lives in Lod (Palestine) (yPes 5:3, 32a). According to BT (bPes 62b) he was born in southern Palestine (דרום), but lives in Nehardea. In this tradition his father is arguing with a Babylonian rabbi, which suggests that the Palestinian version is to be preferred.

In incantation bowls persons are usually designated by their mother’s name, but here we read: מארוי בר באתי דמתקרי אבאבאי בר אבדימי (Maroy son of Batay, who is called Ababay son of Abdimi). I assume that Batay is his mother’s name, Abdimi his father’s and Ababay (=Habib) a nickname.

Josephus begins his and his brother’s story in the following manner: Γίνεται δὲ καὶ περὶ τοὺς ἐν τῇ Μεσοποταμίᾳ καὶ μάλιστατὴν Βαβυλωνίαν οἰκοῦντος ̓Ιουδαίους δεινὴ καὶ ο̓δεμιᾶς ἡστινος(The Jews of Mesopotamia and especially those inhabiting Babylonia now met with a terrible and unparalleled disaster), see Introduction 6.1. He then goes on to tell of the actions of these two brothers, who were obviously Jewish as they belonged to the described community.

I therefore conclude that it is much more likely that he was Babylonian.

There is great confusion about the name of this sage. In bShab 62b he is desgnated רבא, but only in the Vilna print. In the mss. עולא. In the Vilna print to bYoma 35a he is designated הונא (and also in Ms Munich 95 to bShab 129a) but in most of the mss עולא. In the Vilna print to bSuk 26a he is designated יוסף. But in all the mss he is designated יצחק. Only here is he designated in the Vilna print עולא. There is some confusion about this family. According to PT Simlai was born in Nehardea (Babylonia) but lives in Lod (Palestine) (yPes 5:3, 32a). According to BT (bPes 62b) he was born in southern Palestine (דרום), but lives in Nehardea. In (bRhSh 20b) his father is arguing with a Babylonian rabbi, which suggests that the Palestinian version is to be preferred, and see Introduction 7.1.

div.note: אבא means “father” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 2). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. For the Aramaic name see Lipiński, Studies 1, 190-4. אבא is documented on a First Temple Hebrew seal (CWSSS no. 44), and for Arabs ʾBʾ (Harding, ICPIANI, 8).

Jastrow, DTTBYML, 3, identifies this as the Greek name Εὔδημος. However, because the name is as popular for Babylonian amoraim as it is for Palestinian ones (see vol. 2, under Abdimi S-H/M), it is more likely to be a Semitic name with the element אב (father).
אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). The form ʾBH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 16). On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). The form ʾBW is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 17). On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). This name makes perfect sense in Aramaic (=father of the master), but I have not found it recorded elsewhere.
אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). The form ʾBYHN is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 1).
אביי/אבייה means “prayer” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 6).

אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). The meaning of this name is probably “mother’s father.” The form ʾBYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 18). On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.

אב means “father” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1-2). ʾBN is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 16) and ʾBYN in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 1). On names associated with family relationships see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.

אדי means “to swing, throw, pitch” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 16). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 101-2. It is recorded on an Aramaic, Achemanid-period seal (CWSSS no. 759); in 5th C BCE Egypt (TADAE 3, 3.14); and ʾDʾ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 2).
The name ʾDYNT is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 2). It was the name of the famous Palmyrene king, who died 269 CE, and see further under Zenobia (1) F/G.
אהל/אהלא means “tent” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 19-20). The form ʾHL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 82).
אהינא means “a species of late inferior dates” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 20).
אויא/איויא/חיויא means “serpent” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 24). The form ʾWY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 87).
אולפנא/אולפן means “custom, training, instruction; the law” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 26).
אומצא in Aramaic means “a thick piece of meat,” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 27).
The form ʾḤT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 24). The name is associated with the Aramaic word אחת (sister). On names associated with family relationships see vol. Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15.
איבו means “vulture or kite” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 44). The form ʾYB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 87).
Jastrow, DTTBYML, 46, identifies Ihi as a place name in Babylonia, and see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica, 164-8.
איקא means “stallion-goat, buck” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 59).
אמי/אמא means “to say, speak, think” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 74). The form ʾMY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 78). The form ʾMYʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 5).
מימר means “word, command” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 775).
Jastrow, DTTBYML, 98, translates אסר as “to imprison” or “to surround.” The name is otherwise unrecorded.
The name אשו is recorded for Nabateans, (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 154). The form ʾŠY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 50).
אשינא in Aramaic means “to be substantial, dense, strong“ (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 129). The name ʾŠYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 50).

באלי means “hurrying, chasing” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 135). Jastrow suggests interpreting this name as the Latin name Ο̓άλης Βάλης Valens. The forms BʾL/BʾLH are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 91). The form BLY is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 10).
Palmyrene name (BWRPʾ), see Stark, PNPI, 9.
בטי means “bottom, bathing basin” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 156). The forms BṬʿ/BṬW are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 109).
ביזא means “rent, cleft” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 159). The form BSN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 106).
בלח means “to be unsteady, dazzle” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 172). The form BLḤ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 115). The form BLḤY is recorded for a Palmyrene woman (Stark, PNPI, 10).

בל is the name of a Babylonian deity (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 170). The names בלו/בלי are recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 181). The form BL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 115) and for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 9).
בל is the name of a Babylonian deity (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 170). The form BLʿQB is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 10).
The form BRBM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 100).
ברדילא/בורדלא is an Aramaization of the Latin burdillus “club, whip, blows, lashes” in (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 149).
ברונא means “dear little son, darling” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 190). The form BRN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 103).

ברוקא in Aramaic means “morning star” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 191). BRQ is recorded as a name for Arabs, (Harding, ICPIANI, 102), and is a biblical name (Judg 3:6). BRWQ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 79).
The name seems Aramaic meaning ‘blessed lion.’ Other names of this sort are also recorded on incantation bowls, though not elsewhere, see Introduction 6.5.2.1.

The name seems Aramaic meaning ‘blessed gift/load.’ Other names of this sort are also recorded on incantation bowls, though not elsewhere, see Introduction 6.5.2.1. On the theophoric suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.5.
The name seems Aramaic meaning ‘blessed Yishai’ (perhaps referring to David’s father). Other names of this sort are also recorded on incantation bowls, though not elsewhere, see Introduction 6.5.2.1.
The name seems Aramaic meaning ‘blessed Lord.’ Other names of this sort are also recorded on incantation bowls, though not elsewhere, see Introduction 6.5.2.1.
The name is not found elsewhere, but names beginning with the element בר (son) are Aramaic, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.2.1.1.5, p. 12.
The form BRŠMŠ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 12).
BTR as a name is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 92). On the suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.2, p. 25.
גביה means “tall” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 206).

גדיא means “kid” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 211). However, this name is probably derived from the Aramaic god of fortune, גד, as is the biblical name of גד, the son of Jacob. On this name in the talmudic period see E. Friedheim, “The Names ‘Gad’, ‘Gada’ and ‘Gadya’ among Palestinian and Babylonian Sages and the Rabbinic Struggle against Pagan Influences,” in A. Demsky (ed.), These are the Names: Studies in Jewish Onomastics 3 (Ramat Gan 2002) 117-26 (Hebrew). Names deriving from גד were popular, (e.g. CWSSS, nos. 12, 467, and others in that collection). גדיא is documented as a name for Nabataeans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 214) and GDYʾ for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 81).
Palmyrene name, GDRṢW (Stark, PNPI, 13).
The form JʾL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 151).
גוריא means “cub, young lion” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 227). גור and גורו are documented as Idumean names (AOFCI, nos. 62-4, 69). GWRʾ and GWRY are documented in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 81).
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
The word גורקא in Babylonian Aramaic means “unripe fruit,” see Sokoloff, DJBA, 272.
גידל means “pupil” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 235). The name גדלו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 218). The form JDL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 155).
גזה/גיזה means “shearing, wool cut” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 236). The form JZʾ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 160).
גמדא means “contracted, atrophied” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 252). The form JMD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 166).

גניבה/גנבה means “theft” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML 259). The name גנבו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 239). The form JNB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 169). GNBʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 14).
דהבא means “gold” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 281). ÅHB is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 259).
The form DMY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 244).
דקלי means “palm-gardner” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 319). The form DQL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 241).
דכי, דכיא in Aramaic means “clear, pure, clean, guiltless” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 307).
דלא means “to draw, raise” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 309). The form DLY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 242).
דרג/דרג means “step, stairs, ladder” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 320-1). The form DRJ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 238).
The form DR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 238).
The forms HDM (Harding, ICPIANI, 611) and HÅM (Harding, ICPIANI, 612) are recorded for Arabs.
הון/הונא means “proper conduct” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 339). The name הנא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 307). The form HNʾ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 625).

According to Jastrow, DTTBYML, 348, היני is “a Babylonian place near Pumbeditha.” The names הנא/הנאו/הניאו are recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 307, 308, 311). The form HNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 628).
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
The name הלן is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 304). The form HLN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 622).
The transliteration is mine. Isbell offered none.
There is no etymological or linguistic explanation for this name. For a name midrash on it see bQid 25a and see also Lifschitz, “Names and Nicknames,” 97-8.
The name הנאו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 308). The form HNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 628).

The name והבאל is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI 175). The name והבאלת is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 338). The form WHBʾLH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 651). The form WHBLT is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 15-6).
Palmyrene name ZBDBWL (Stark, PNPI, 16-7).
The name ZBDLH is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 17).

זבינא means “object of purchase” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 379). The names זבינא/זבינו/זבנו/זבני are recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 374-7). The form ZBNʾ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 294).
זוטרא means “small, young, junior” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 386).
The forms ZN/ZNY are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 302).
זעירא means “small, young, tender, lesser” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 407). ZʿRN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 298).
The name חבו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 404). The form ḤBW is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 175).

The root חבב means “to love” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 415-7). חבובא/חיבובא means “beloved” (Jastrow, ibid. 450). ḤBWB is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 87). ḤBB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 172).

Neither this name nor any of its variants are mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, but they clearly belong to the family of biblical names such as יוחנן and חנניה, see vol. 1, Honi S-H/M p. 377. One may assume that חוני/חניה/חוניו are Aramicized, as befits the post-biblical period. It appears that in post-biblical times this name became identified as uniquely Jewish, and was, as a rule, not used by non-Jews. Thus, it is a rare case where a non-biblical name is considered uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.2.
חיוא/חיווא means “animal” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 452). The name חויא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 420).
The form ḤYWT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 212). On the theophoric suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.5.
חייא means “life” or “midwife” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 454). ḤYW is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 211). חיא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 429).
Palmyrene name ḤYRN (Stark, PNPI, 21-2).

חלבון means “glare, white of an egg” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 464). The name חלבו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 442). The form ḤLB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 197).

חליפה means “replacement, substitution” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 469). This name is recorded in Palmyra (ḤLYPʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 88). ḤLF is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 198). The Nabateans used חליפו (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 448).

חלפתא means “willow” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 472). The name ḤLPTʾ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 89). ḤLF is recorded as a name for Idumaeans (AOFCI, 99) and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 198).

חמא means “father-in-law” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 475). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. The name is recorded in Palmyra (ḤMʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 89). ḤM is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 199). The Nabatean חמיו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 461).

חנא means “grace, favor, loveliness” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 481). The name חנאו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 468). The form ḤNY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 207). The form ḤNʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 23).
ḤNL is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 206).
חסא means “lettuce” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 485). The form ḤS is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 188).
חקלייא and חקלאה mean “field laborer“ (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 497).
The form ḤŠ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 189). The form ḤŠY is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 23).
טבות/טבאות means “good manner, well, properly” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 516). The forms ṬB/ṬBY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 386).
The name טביו is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI 174). The name is probably derived from the Hebrew יום טוב (festival).
טבלא means “bell” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 518).
Palmyrene name (YDYBʿL, see Stark, PNPI, 24-5).
The name means “good salvation.” It is not recorded elsewhere.
The name יחיא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 525b).
ייבא means in Aramaic “it agrees with, corresponds to” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 560).
The name ימורו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 530).
ינקא/ינוקא in Aramaic means “suckling child,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 581-2.
Palmyrene name (YRḤBWL, see Stark, PNPI, 26-7). It may mean “The month of Bul,” see 1 Kgs 6:38.
Palmyrene name (YRḤY, see Stark, PNPI, 27-8).
יתמא means “orphan“ in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 604). The form YTM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 657).
כהנא means “priest” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 615).
כיילא means “measure” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 631). The form KYLY is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 29).
לילי/ליליא means “night” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 707). The form LLY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 520).
The forms LM/LMḤ are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 520).
מולדה means “birth-time” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 742). The name מלדי is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 635). The form MLD is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 564).
Harding, ICPIANI, 559, records the form MFLH for Arabs.
Palmyrene name (MZBNʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 30).

Names with the element מחל are recorded in the Bible (e.g. מחלה – Num 26:33; מחלי – Ex 6:19 etc.) This name could be from the same family. It could also be a theophorical name, with the element אל, but the name is not recorded elsewhere.
מחלף means “sharp-knife” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 762).
The transliteration is according to CAMIBBM. AMB, p. 135, gives the transliteration Maḥlepā.

מטה/מטן in Hebrew means “downward” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 766). The name is recorded in Palmyra (MṬN Stark, PNPI, 94). MṬY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 551). מטיו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 625). Justi, INB, 200, also records the Iranian name Matn.
Palmyrene name (MLʾ, see Stark, PNPI, 31).
ממל means “olive press” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 795).
The form MNYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 570).
מסרק means “comb, strigil” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 811-2).
Palmyrene name (MʿN, see Stark, PNPI, 34).
The form MFYŠ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 559).
Palmyrene name (MQY, see Stark, PNPI, 35).
Palmyrene name (MQYMW, see Stark, PNPI, 35-7).
The form MRB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 537). The form MRBNʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 37).

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834). This name MRY is recorded on an Aramaic First Temple seal (CWSSS no. 808), and for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 542). The name מרי is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 691).

The name is otherwise not attested, nor is any etimology forthcoming. Because the name is common both for Babylonian amoraim and on incantations bowls, it may be an Iranian name, but Justi, INB, does not record it.
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
Palmyrene name (NBWZBD, see Stark, PNPI, 38).
The name means “fire of Bel” in Aramaic. בל is the name of a Babylonian deity (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 170).

This form is a variation on יוחנן (see under Yohanan (26) B/M in vol. 1, p. 135) and חנניה (see under Ḥananiah (27) B/M in vol. 1, p. 104). For further details see under Honi S-H/M, n. 1 vol. 1, p. 378. It may have been a variation for יוחנן or חנניה used specifically in rabbinic circles. NḤWN and NḤYN are recorded as names for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 583).
ניוול means “ugliness, disgrace” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 902). The form NWL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 604).
The form NN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 601).

נעים means “pleasing, lovely” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 919). The name נעום is recorded for Edomeans (AOFCI, 80, 90, 121, 129). The form NʿYN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 595). NʿYM is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 39).

סבא means “gray, old, elder, grandfather” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 948). On family members as names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.1, p. 15. In the Bible (e.g. 1 Chr 1:9) this is the name of an African nation. Only in post-biblical times did it become a suitable name for Jews, see vol. 1, S-H/M, pp. 395-6. SBʾ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 308) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 101).
סומקא means “red” in Aramaic (Jastrow DTTBYML, 966). SMK is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 329). This form is recorded as a nickname for Isaac (10) B/M.
The word סורג in Hebrew means “lattich work” (Jastrow DTTBYML, 969). Perhaps this is a variation on the Latin name Sergius L/M.
This name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
סחורא means “circuit” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 970). The form SḤR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 311).
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
סלא means “basket” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 993). The name סלי is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 770). The form SL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 324).
סמא means “drug, medicine, poison, paint” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 998). The form SM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 327). The form SMYʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 41).
סעורא means “visitation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1010). The form SʿR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 320).
ספרא means “scribe” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1018). For most people in this corpus with this name perhaps it is no more than a nickname indicating occupation.
The name ʿGʾ is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 42-3).
Palmyrene name ʿGYLW (Stark, PNPI, 43-4).
Transliteration according to Cantineau. Schlumberger, Palmerène, 143, gives the transliteration ʿOgeilu.

עדן means “refreshment, pleasure” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1045). The name עדנו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 844). The forms ʿDN/ʿDWN are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 410). The form ʿDN is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 44).
עויא means “serpent” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1049). The name עויו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 855). The form ‘W is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 447).
עולא means “infant, nursling, child” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1050). The form ʿLH is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 432).
עזא/עיזא means “goat” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1068). The form ʿZ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 417). The form ʿZY is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 44).
עטר/עטיר means “distinguished” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1064).
עילאי means “high, uppermost” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1069). The name עילי/עילו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 882). The form ʿYL is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 451).
The form ʿLYŠ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 45).
עינא means “eye-sight” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1071). The form ʿYNW is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 451).
עיפא means “cover, veil” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1073). The form ʿF is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 425).
For this Nabatean name see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 894.
עצרא means “juice” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1103). The name עצרו/עצר is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 934-5). The form ʿṢR is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 423).
ערבא means “woof” or “bondsman, surety” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1111). The form ʿRB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPRANI, 414). ערביו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 939).
ערג in Aramaic means “groan, pant” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1113). The form ʿRGN is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 45).
The name is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32 (1991) no. 947.
The form ʿTʿQB is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 46-7).
The form ṢYT is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 379). The form ṢTʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48).
The form QWQWN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 491). The form QWQH is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48).
קאזא/קזא means “cotton-seed” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1306).

קטין means “slender, thin, fine” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1348). הקטן is a name recorded in the Bible (Ezra 2:12). QṬN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 484). The Nabatean קטינו is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1017).

קיום means “preservation, storage” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1356). The name קיומא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1018). The form QYM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 492). The form QYMY is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48). For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 2.
The form QSY is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 482). The form QYSʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48).
קיסנא means “piece of wood, chip” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1364). The form QSYNʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 48).
The name קיפו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1030.
קאקוזא in Babylonian Aramic means “type of vessel,” see Sokoloff, DJBA, 1035.

קרנא means “horn” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1422). For a name midrash on this sage’s name see bShab 108a and bBQ 89a-b) and see Lifschitz, “Names and Nicknames,” 96-7. The form QRN is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 480). The form QRYN is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 49).
The name רוחו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1060). The form RWḤ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 290).
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
רחבה means “open market place” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1465). The form RḤB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 272).
רחום means “merciful” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1465). The form RḤM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 273).
ריכשא means horse in Babylonian Aramaic, see Sokoloff, DJBA, 1076.
רקתא means “alluvial ground bank” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1498).

ריש/רישא means “head” or alternatively “poison” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1477-8). RŠʾY is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 278). The Nabatean רישו is also recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1071).
The name שאלהי is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1092). The form ŠʾLM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 337). The form ŠʾYLʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 50).
The transliteration is mine. Isbell, n. 69, offered none.
The form ŠJB is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 340).
שוחט means slaughterer in Hebrew, see Isa 66:3.
שיזבו/שיזבותא means “safety, refuge” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1559). The form ŠZBʾ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 348).
This name is documented on Hebrew seals from the First Temple period (CWSSS no. 280 and perhaps also no. 588).

In Aramaic שיקוייא means “drink, potion” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1567) and שקיינא means “drink, liquid, infusion” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1622). The form שקיא is recorded as a name for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1186).
שירא means “silk” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1568). The form ŠRʾ is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 344).
שמלה means “garment” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1596).
Palmyrene name (ŠʿDY, see Stark, PNPI, 53).
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.

שפיר means either “fetus” or “handsome, pleasing, good, cheerful” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1616). ŠFR is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 352). This is a case where the male name is probably derived from the female שפרה (B/F), see vol. 1, Shapir (S-H/M), p. 415.
תוספאה in Aramaic means “one who uses vowel letters freely, who writes plene,” (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1654).

תומא means “simplicity” or “garlic” or “fringe” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1654). TʾM is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 127). The Nabatean name תאומא is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1193).

תורא means “ox” or “row, line” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1656). The name תורא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1205). In Pesiq Rab 14 (Parah) this name is explained as emanating from תורתא – cow – and as a nickname given to a convert because of the manner he converted אמרו רבותינו: מעשה היה בישראל אחד שהיה לו פרה אחת חורשת. נתמעטה ידו ומכרה לגוי אחד. כיון שלקחה הגוי וחרשה עמו ששת ימים של חול. בשבת הוציאה שתחרוש עמו ורבצה לו תחת העול. היה הולך ומכה אותה והיא אינה זזה ממקומה. כיון שראה כן הלך ואמר לאותו ישראל שמכרה לו: בוא טול פרתך, שמא צער יש בה, שהרי כמה אני מכה אותה, היא אינה זזה ממקומה. אותו ישראל הבין לומר בשביל של שבת והיתה למודה לנוח בשבת. א"ל: בוא ואני מעמידה. כיוון שבא ואמר לה באזנה: פרה, פרה, את יודעת כשהיית ברשותי היית חורשת ימי החול, בשבת היית נינוח, עכשיו שגרמו עוונותי ואת ברשות גוי, בבקשה ממך, עמדי וחרשי. ומיד עמדה וחרשה. א"ל אותו הגוי: אני מבקשך, טול פרתך. עד עכשיו אני בא ומיסב אחריך שתהא בא ומעמידה. על אחת חוץ מזו ומזו, איני מניחך עד שתאמר לי מה עשית באזנה. אני נתייגעתי בה והכיתי אותה ולא עמדה. התחיל אותו ישראל מפייסו ואומר לו: לא כישוף ולא כשפים עשיתי, אלא כך וכך הסחתי לה באזנה ועמדה וחרשה. מיד נתיירא הגוי. אמר: ומה אם פרה, שאין לה לא שיחה ולא דעת, הכירה את בוראה, אני שייצרני יוצרי בדמותו ונתן בי דעת, איני הולך ומכיר את בוראי? מיד בא ונתגייר, ולמד וזכה לתורה. והיו קוראים שמו יוחנן בן תורתה. (Our rabbis said: There was the case of an Israelite who had a ploughing cow. He became poor and sold her to a certain gentile. Once the gentile took her, she ploughed with him on six work days. When he took her out on Shabbat to plough, she lay down. He hit her continuously but she did not move. Seeing that this was the case, he went to the Israelite who sold her and said to him: Come take your cow, perhaps she is sick. As hard as I beat her she will not budge. This Israelite understood that this was because of Shabbat and that she was used to resting on Shabbat. He said come and I will make her stand. Coming to the cow, he whispered in her ear: Cow, Cow, you know, when you were under my [control] you plowed on work days, and rested on Shabbat. Now that my sins have impoverished me and you are in the possession of a gentile, please stand and plough. Immediately she stood up and ploughed. That gentile said to him: Please, take your cow. Should I come everytime and bother you to make her work? And I will also not let you go until you tell me what you did to her ear. I attempted everything and beat her and she did not stand. That Israelite began calming him, and said to him: I did no magic nor witchcraft. I only said so and so in her ear and she stood and ploughed. That gentile became fearful. He said: If a cow, who has no speech or reason, recognizes her creator, how much more so I, who were created in his image and likeness and he gave me reason, should I not also recognize my creator? Immediately he converted and studied and became a scholar and they called him Yohanan son of Torata [=cow]).
This name derives from the Hebrew root חלף (exchange).
The form TYMḤʾ is recorded for Palmyrenes (Stark, PNPI, 55).
The name is not recorded elsewhere, see Introduction 1.6.
CIS transliteration. Cantineau gives Taimarso.
תמר means “palm, date” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1679).

תנחומין means “consolation” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1681). The name תנחם is documented in Hebrew and Ammonite First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 707-8, 947). Alternatively, Justi, INB, 322, records the Iranian name “Tanhā.”
